# Challenges of Decarbonization {#challenges .center}

## Challenges of Decarbonization {#challenges-outline}

* How hard will it be to reduce CO~2~ emissions?
  * {+} Nordhaus:
    * What technology can replace fossil fuels?
    * What policies can stimulate innovation, investment, production, purchase of clean technology?
  * {+} Pielke:
    * The biggest challenge is cost: $RE < C$
    * Make clean technology cheaper than fossil fuels and the problem is solved.

## Perspective: US CO~2~ Emissions {#us-emissions .ninety}

```{r us_emissions}
us = get_kaya_data(region_code = "USA") %>% filter(! is.na(ef)) %>%
  arrange(year, region)

plot_kaya(us, "F", start_year = 0, stop_year = 3000,
          y_lab = expression(paste("Energy-related ", CO[2], 
                                   " emissions (million metric tons)"))) + 
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ifelse(year == 1973, "Arab Oil Embargo", 
                                      ifelse(year == 1979, "Iran Revolution", 
                                             NA))), 
                   size = 6,
                   nudge_y = 100, point.padding = 0.75, box.padding = 1, 
                   na.rm = T, 
                   arrow = arrow(length = unit(0.5, "char"), type = "closed", 
                                 angle = 20))
```

## Rate of Decarbonization {#decarbonization-rate .ninety}

```{r us_decarbonization, fig.height=7, fig.width=10}
us_trends <- get_top_down_trends(region_code = "USA", quiet = TRUE)

policy_F = (1 - 0.83) * filter(us, year == 2005)$F
implied_F_trend = log(policy_F / filter(us, year == 2009)$F) / (2050 - 2009)
implied_ef_trend = implied_F_trend - us_trends$G

ef_fit = us %>% filter(year >= 1980) %>%
  lm(log(ef) ~ year, data = .)
  
actual_ef_trend  = ef_fit %>% tidy() %>% filter(term == "year") %$% estimate

p <- plot_kaya(us, "ef", start_year = 1990, log_scale = TRUE, 
               trend_line = TRUE, font_size = 15,
               y_lab = expression(paste(CO[2], " intensity of GDP (tonnes/$1000)")))
p$layers[[2]]$aes_params <- 1
p$layers[[3]]$aes_parames <- 1.5
p
```

::: {.eighty}

* {+} 2009 policy goal: US emissions 83% less than 2005 by 2050
* {+} _ef_ must drop by `r round(100 * abs(implied_ef_trend),1)`% per year
* {+} Actual rate has been about `r round(100 * abs(actual_ef_trend), 1)`% per 
>   year

:::

## Implied Decarbonization {#implied-decarbonization}
```{r implied_decarb}
start_year = tail(us$year, 1)
start_ef = tail(us$ef, 1)
stop_year = 2050

implied_decarb_us <- us %>% select(year, Historical = ef) %>% 
  bind_rows(tibble(year = seq(start_year + 1, stop_year), Historical = NA)) %>% 
  augment(ef_fit, newdata = .) %>% mutate(.fitted = exp(.fitted)) %>%
  rename("Historical Trend" = .fitted) %>% 
  mutate("Implied Decarbonization" = 
           ifelse(year >= start_year, 
                  start_ef * exp(implied_ef_trend * (year - start_year)), 
                  NA))
implied_decarb_us %>% 
  filter(year >= 1980) %>% 
  gather(one_of("Historical", "Historical Trend", "Implied Decarbonization"),
         key = Category, value = ef) %>%
  ggplot(aes(x = year, y = ef, color = Category)) + 
  geom_line(size = 1, na.rm = T) + geom_point(size = 1, na.rm = T) +
  scale_color_brewer(palette = "Dark2") +
  ylim(0,NA) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(1900,2100, 10)) +
  labs(x = "Year", 
       y = expression(paste(CO[2], " intensity (tonnes / $1000 GDP"))) +
  theme(legend.position = c(0.99,0.99), legend.just = c(1,1))
```

## Cost of Decarbonization {#decarb-cost .eightyfive}

```{r lcoe, results='asis'}
# From https://www.eia.gov/forecasts/aeo/pdf/electricity_generation.pdf
lcoe <- data_frame(
  technology = c('Coal (Conventional)',
                 'Coal (Advanced with CCS)',
                 'Gas (Conventional Comb. Cycle)',
                 'Gas (Advanced Comb. Cycle)',
                 'Gas (Advanced with CCS)',
                 'Gas (Conventional Turbine)',
                 'Nuclear (Advanced)',
                 'Geothermal',
                 'Wind',
                 'Wind (Offshore)',
                 'Solar (PV)',
                 'Solar (Thermal)',
                 'Hydroelectric'
  ),
  capacity_factor = c( 75, 85, 87, 87, 87, 30, 90, 91, 40, 45, 25, 20, 58),
  lcoe = c( 80, 139.5, 58.1, 57.2, 84.8, 110.8, 102.8, 45.0, 64.5, 158.1, 84.7, 
            235.9, 67.8)
) %>% mutate(capacity_factor = str_c(capacity_factor, '%'))

# Lazard Cost of Energy and Levelized Cost of Storage 2020
# https://www.lazard.com/perspective/levelized-cost-of-energy-and-levelized-cost-of-storage-2020/
#
lcoe <- tibble(
  technology = c("Solar Rooftop Residential",
                 "Solar Rooftop Business",
                 "Solar Community",
                 "Solar Utility Scale",
                 "Solar Thermal",
                 "Geothermal",
                 "Wind",
                 "Gas",
                 "Nuclear",
                 "Coal"
                 ),
  low =      c(150,  74,  63, 29, 126,  59, 26, 44, 129,  65),
  high =     c(227, 179,  94, 42, 156, 101, 54, 73, 198, 159),
  existing = c( NA,  NA,  NA, NA,  NA,  NA, 86, 28,  29,  41)
)

lcoe <- lcoe %>% mutate(technology = ordered(technology, levels = technology)) 

ggplot(lcoe) + 
  geom_rect(aes(ymin = as.integer(technology) - 0.3, 
                ymax = as.integer(technology) + 0.3, 
                xmin = low, xmax = high,
                color = "New capacity",

  geom_point(aes(x = existing, y = as.integer(technology),

  scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq_along(levels(lcoe$technology)), 
                     labels = levels(lcoe$technology)) + 
  scale_x_continuous(limits = c(0, NA), 
                     expand = expansion(mult = c(0, 0.05), add = 0)) +
  labs(x = "Levelized Cost ($ per megawatt-hour)", y = NULL,

  theme(legend.position = c(0.99, 0.99), legend.justification = c(1,1))
```

## Challenge of decarbonizing {#challenge}

```{r decarb, fig.height=7, fig.width=7}
world <- get_kaya_data("World")
p_e = plot_kaya(world, "e", start_year = 1980, 
                trend_line = TRUE, log_scale = TRUE, font_size = 15,
                y_lab = "Energy intensity of economy")
p_f = plot_kaya(world, "f", start_year = 1970, stop_year = 2000,
                trend_line = TRUE, log_scale = TRUE, font_size = 15,
                y_lab = expression(paste(CO[2], " intensity of energy supply")))

p_e$layers[[2]]$aes_params <- 1
p_e$layers[[3]]$aes_parames <- 1.5

p_f$layers[[2]]$aes_params <- 1
p_f$layers[[3]]$aes_parames <- 1.5

trend_e <- world %>% filter(year >= 1980) %>% 
  lm(log(e) ~ year, data = .) %>% tidy() %>% filter(term == "year") %$% estimate

trend_f <- world %>% filter(year >= 1970, year <= 2000) %>% 
  lm(log(f) ~ year, data = .) %>% tidy() %>% filter(term == "year") %$% estimate

p_e
p_f
```

::: {.seventy style="margin:0;position:relative;top:-2rem;"} 
* {+} Trend in _e_ (1980--present): `r label_percent(0.1)(trend_e)` per year.
* {+} Trend in _f_ (1970--2000): `r label_percent(0.1)(trend_f)` per year.
  * {+} Trend reversed in 2000, but rapid decrease since around 2008.
* {+} So far: Decarbonization driven much more by efficiency than clean energy.
* {+} Rebound: greater efficiency &rarr; more consumption.
:::

## Innovation Policy {#innovation-policy .eighty}

::::::::::::{.columns}
:::::::::{.column}
* {+1} Knowing price of CO~2~ will rise provides incentive to invest in R&D
* {+2} Valley of Death:
  * {+3} Technology looks promising in laboratory
  * {+4} Potential for big profits
  * {+5} Many years, lots of money to turn laboratory device into product
    * {+6} Product development might fail
    * {+7} Product might not sell
    * {+8} Competitors might copy product
    * {+9} Valley of death
  * {+10} Double externality
    1. Inventors don't get all the value of their inventions
    2. Polluters don't pay the costs of pollution
  * {+11} Government support to cross valley of death
:::::::::

# Pielke's Policy Proposal {#pielke-policy-sec .center}

## Pielke's Policy Proposal: {#pielke-proposal}

* {+} Competition within government
* {+} Public-works model
* {+} Demonstration projects
* {+} Government as consumer of energy innovations
  * Federal government is the largest consumer of energy in the U.S.
    * 350,000 buildings
    * 600,000 vehicles
* {+} $5/ton carbon tax ($0.04 per gallon gas)
  * invest in clean-energy R&D
* {+} Monitor progress
* {+} Develop "plan B" (geoengineering)


## Obliquity {#obliquity .center}

* Appeal to people who don't care about climate change
  * Cheaper energy
  * Reduce pollution (smog, etc.)
  * Reduce dependence on foreign oil
